entries.name: Ruins of Salar
entries: Im lichtlosen Tiefpunkt des {@book Crystalfen Caverns|TDCSR|4|Crystalfen Caverns}, direkt unter dem pr√§chtigen {@book Port of Emon|TDCSR|4|Port of Emon}, ruhen die ewig schlummernden Ruinen von Salar. Kein Sterblicher hat diese Ruinen - einst die Hauptstadt eines m√§chtigen {@creature aboleth} Herrschaftsgebiets - je gesehen und ist mit dem Verstand an die Oberfl√§che zur√ºckgekehrt, um die Geschichte zu erz√§hlen. Salar ist nur in Mythen und Legenden als die unsichtbare Stadt bekannt, weil sterbliche Augen die fremdartige Architektur nicht sehen k√∂nnen, ohne ihren zerbrechlichen Geist zu zerst√∂ren. Salar wird von {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} Gelehrten und Arch√§ologen als urbane Legende betrachtet. Dennoch glauben viele an ihre Existenz, denn zahlreiche Gelehrte kehrten von Expeditionen in die tiefen H√∂hlen zur√ºck, deren Geist von jenseitigen Kr√§ften zerr√ºttet war.

Diejenigen, die aus Salar zur√ºckgekehrt sind, haben Tageb√ºcher mitgebracht, die mit zunehmend verr√ºckten Notizen gef√ºllt sind. Die verst√§ndlichsten ihrer Aufzeichnungen besagen, dass alles, was von der zerst√∂rten Stadt √ºbrig geblieben ist, smaragdgr√ºne Marmorstrukturen von unergr√ºndlichem Design sind, die sich zu verschieben und zu schimmern scheinen, w√§hrend das Auge versucht, sie zu verstehen, und die sich durch die Zeit bewegen, w√§hrend sie im Raum statisch bleiben.

Die einst ber√ºhmte Arch√§ologin Karaline von Ethro behauptete, Visionen von Salar gehabt zu haben, in denen sie eine unterirdische Stadt mit gewundenen S√§ulen beschrieb, die h√∂her als jeder Turm waren und den Sitz der Oberfl√§chenwelt vom Grundgestein der Erde k√ºssten. An der Spitze der zentralen S√§ule schwebt eine riesige perlmuttfarbene Scheibe. Diese so genannte Mondscheibe taucht die gesamte Stadt in ein beunruhigendes, milchiges Licht, das sich unheimlich in den smaragdfarbenen T√ºrmen bricht.

Karaline von Ethro ist schon lange tot, und ihr Tagebuch - die bei weitem koh√§renteste Aufzeichnung √ºber die Unsichtbare Stadt - ist ein apokryphes Artefakt. Die {@book Arcana Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical} bewahrten es in einem streng bewachten Tresor auf, was seine Mystik nur noch verst√§rkte. Das Tagebuch wurde jedoch vor langer Zeit gestohlen, und seitdem werden Dutzende von Manuskripten, die angeblich das Von Ethro Tagebuch sein sollen, auf Schwarzm√§rkten in ganz Tal'Dorei verkauft. Jeder, der das Gl√ºck - oder das Pech - hat, das echte Tagebuch zu finden, erf√§hrt ein schreckliches Geheimnis, das die {@book Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical} seit Jahrzehnten f√ºr sich behalten haben: Dutzende, vielleicht Hunderte von {@book aboleths|TDCSR|7|aboleths} √ºberleben in Salar. Ihr Meister, Durrom von den Smaragdaugen, lebt im Verborgenen weiter, w√§hrend er seine Armee von Sklaven vergr√∂√üert und alles √ºber die unwissenden Oberfl√§chenbewohner lernt, was er kann. Durroms ultimatives Ziel ist es, die vergessenen S√§ulen der Erde unter {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} zu zerst√∂ren und die Stadt in sein unterirdisches Reich st√ºrzen zu lassen.

entries.name: Karaline von Ethro
entries: Die Arch√§ologin, Anthropologin und au√üergew√∂hnliche Forscherin Karaline von Ethro war eine menschliche Abenteurerin und Erfinderin. Auf ihre Entw√ºrfe geht der Sonnenstrahlkompass zur√ºck, ein Ger√§t, das den Benutzer immer nach der Sonne ausrichtet, indem es ein kleines Licht an der Spitze der Nadel in einer Glaskugel ausstrahlt, so dass sie sich in alle Richtungen drehen kann - ein sehr n√ºtzliches Werkzeug bei der Erkundung unterirdischer Gebiete. Doch trotz ihrer Entdeckungen und Erfindungen ist sie vor allem daf√ºr bekannt, dass sie verr√ºckt wurde, nachdem sie angeblich Visionen von den Ruinen von Salar hatte. Karalines Wahnsinn f√ºhrte schlie√ülich zu ihrem tragischen Ableben im jungen Alter von 37 Jahren.

entries.name: Secrets Within Secrets (mid-level)
entries: Die Charaktere werden von Jomen Tash angesprochen, einem ernsthaften Halbelf-Magier der {@book Arcana Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical}, der behauptet, Seiten aus dem verlorenen Von Ethro Journal erhalten zu haben. Er teilt seine Forschungen mit den Charakteren und heuert sie an, ihn in die Ruinen zu begleiten, wobei er ihnen verspricht, dass er ihren Geist vor jeglichem fremden Einfluss sch√ºtzen wird. Doch in Wahrheit war Jomen einst ein Mitglied der {@book Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical}, doch seit kurzem hat er seine Interessen mit den geheimnisvollen Zielen der {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles} in Einklang gebracht. F√ºhrt er die Charaktere in die Gefahr, indem er ihnen nur gef√§lschte Kritzeleien als Wegweiser gibt, oder ist er tats√§chlich im Besitz eines Teils von Karaline von Ethros Beschreibung der {@book Salar|TDCSR|4|Ruins of Salar} und ihrer Gefahren?

entries.name: Scar of the Cinder King
entries: Man dachte, das Land um {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} w√ºrde sich nie wieder vollst√§ndig von {@book Thordak's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} √ºberw√§ltigender Urgewalt erholen. Seine Anwesenheit hat nicht nur seine Feinde verbrannt, sondern auch das Land selbst verwundet. Nach der {@book Cinder King's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} Niederlage baten die {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} die Feuer-Ashari, aus den fernen L√§ndern von {@book Issylra|TDCSR|4|Issylra} nach {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} zu reisen und ihre Weisheit zu vermitteln.

Die schrecklichen {@book Scar of the Cinder King|TDCSR|4|Scar of the Cinder King} und {@book Thordak's Crater|TDCSR|4|7. Thordak's Crater}, die beide von der krebsartigen, feurigen Magie des roten Drachens verdreht wurden, wurden von den Druiden der Feuer-Aschari im Laufe von etwa f√ºnfzehn Jahren geheilt - ein Akt, von dem die kl√ºgsten K√∂pfe der {@book Arcana Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical} dachten, er w√ºrde eine Epoche in Anspruch nehmen. Noch immer wehen gelegentlich wei√üe Aschewolken √ºber die Felder in der Umgebung von {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, aber die letzten Erinnerungen an den {@book Cinder King's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} Terror beginnen zu verschwinden.

Dennoch hinterlie√üen die Feuer-Ashari eine Gruppe von vier Druiden, die von einem weiblichen Halb-Ork namens Lorkathar angef√ºhrt werden. Sie leben in einer kleinen steinernen Festung, die als Au√üenposten von Flamereach bekannt ist - eine Verteidigungsanlage, die genutzt wurde, als die Narbe noch Wesen der Flamme und des Hasses hervorbrachte. Sie warnen alle, die die Festung betreten, eindringlich davor, Elementarmagie jeglicher Art - insbesondere Feuermagie - zu verwenden, da diese Beschw√∂rungen die immer noch zarte Trennung zwischen der Materiellen Dimension und der Elementarebene des Feuers zum Schwingen bringen und zerrei√üen k√∂nnten.

entries.name: Reopening Wounds (any level)
entries: Die {@book The Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari} von Pyrah haben behauptet, dass die {@book Scar of the Cinder King|TDCSR|4|Scar of the Cinder King} geheilt ist - doch es gibt Ger√ºchte, dass ein Vertreter von Pyrah bei den {@book Arcana Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical} wegen der Narbe Rat gesucht hat {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} {@book Erudite Quarter|TDCSR|4|Erudite Quarter}. entries.name: Ruins of O'Noa (New O'Noa)

items.name: Village:
entries: Einwohnerzahl: 310 (83% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 17% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

Die ersten menschlichen Kolonisatoren der Tal'Dorei √ºberquerten das Ozmit-Meer, trotzten schrecklichen St√ºrmen und t√∂dlichen Wellen und landeten in {@book Daggerbay|TDCSR|4|Daggerbay}. Von dort aus gr√ºndeten sie die Hafenstadt O'Noa, und obwohl die Stadt schnell an Reichtum und Einfluss gewann, wurden die ersten Siedler von den {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} von {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} mit Misstrauen empfangen. Als K√∂nig Warren {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} den Thron von {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} bestieg, erlitt keine Stadt gr√∂√üere Verw√ºstungen als die umk√§mpfte Region O'Noa. Sie war Schauplatz einer der {@book Scattered War's|TDCSR|2|The Scattered War} blutigsten Schlachten, und die entfesselten arkanen Energien legten die Stadt in Schutt und Asche und verunstalteten das Land f√ºr immer. Erbaut in einer verfluchten Bucht und ohne fruchtbares Land, wurde nach dem Krieg vereinbart, dass weder die neue Nation der Tal'Dorei noch die {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} versuchen w√ºrden, die Stadt wieder aufzubauen, sondern sie als Erinnerung an die Schrecken der {@book Scattered War|TDCSR|2|The Scattered War} stehen lassen w√ºrden.

Im Laufe der Jahrhunderte des Verfalls wurden die Ruinen zu einem Zufluchtsort f√ºr Ge√§chtete und Verbannte, die ihre Zuflucht New O'Noa nannten. Sie machten diesen Ort des Elends und des Staubs zu einem Zufluchtsort f√ºr alle, die von der Gesellschaft versto√üen wurden. Obwohl einige der Bewohner von New O'Noa aufgrund von Angst und Vorurteilen aus ihrer Heimat verbannt wurden - wie Menschen mit schlechtem Schicksal, die unter dem {@book full light of Ruidus|TDCSR|2|Catha and Ruidus} {@homebrew |(see page 9)} geboren wurden - sind die meisten von ihnen Diebe und Verbrecher. New O'Noa wird von einem charismatischen Tiefling namens Waken regiert, der durch schmeichelnde Worte und gezielte Morde zu Ansehen gelangt ist.

F√ºr Au√üenstehende wirkt New O'Noa immer noch verlassen. Seine Bewohner leben und verstecken sich vor neugierigen Blicken inmitten alter Steinruinen und ihrer Katakomben. Wer sich zu tief in die Ruinen hineinwagt, wird nur selten wieder gesehen oder geh√∂rt - es sei denn, seine Angeh√∂rigen k√∂nnen ein f√ºrstliches L√∂segeld aufbringen.

entries.name: This Too Solid Flesh (mid-level)

Ein {@item suude|TDCSR} H√§ndler namens Shef Silverleaf hat gro√üe Schulden bei Waken, dem Anf√ºhrer des gesetzlosen Dorfes. Die Figuren kommen ins Spiel, als Waken sie heimlich anheuert, um seine Schulden einzutreiben - vielleicht unter falschem Vorwand, um seine illegalen Gesch√§fte zu verbergen.

Als die Gruppe Shef aufsp√ºrt, finden sie mehr, als sie erwartet haben: Sein K√∂rper wurde in feste {@item silver|PHB} verwandelt. Ein {@creature Remnant cultist|TDCSR} {@homebrew |(see page 252)} lauert in den Schatten von New {@book O'Noa|TDCSR|4|Ruins of O'Noa (New O'Noa)} und hat seit fast drei Monaten {@item suude|TDCSR} von Shef gekauft. Shef hat seine geheime Identit√§t aufgedeckt und ihn zur Rede gestellt - aber die Magie des Magiers, die durch die {@item suude|TDCSR} chaotisch geworden ist, hat Shef in einen festen {@item silver|PHB} verwandelt. Waken wird Shefs festen {@item silver|PHB} Leichnam als Bezahlung annehmen - aber was w√§re, wenn der silberh√§utige Mann noch am Leben w√§re und auf magische Weise weggehen k√∂nnte? Und was ist mit dem Kultisten, der ihn verwandelt hat?

entries.name: Seashale Mountains

entries.name: From Hell's Heart (low-level)

entries.name: Visa Isle
entries: Vierzig Meilen vor der K√ºste von {@book Bladeshimmer Shoreline|TDCSR|4|Bladeshimmer Shoreline}, westlich von {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse}, sto√üen zwei Inseln schwarze Rauchwolken in den offenen Himmel. Diejenigen, die den dichten Dschungel erkundet haben und zur√ºckgekehrt sind, behaupten, nur gew√∂hnliche Wildschweine und - im schlimmsten Fall - ungew√∂hnlich gro√üe Feuerk√§fer und Gottesanbeterinnen gefunden zu haben. Sie waren die Gl√ºcklichen. Sie kamen nicht unvorbereitet in die Ruinen von Vos'sykriss und trafen auch nicht auf die schlangenartigen Geister, die in den alten Hallen spuken. Die einzige Expedition, die sich in die Ruinen von Vos'sykriss wagte und √ºberlebte, um davon zu berichten, kehrte nach {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} zur√ºck, gerade als die {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} √ºber die Stadt herfielen. entries.name: Awakening the Sleepers (mid-level)
entries: In alten Zeiten war Vos'sykriss der Sitz eines Serpentfolk-Reiches, das den S√ºden der Tal'Dorei beherrschte. Vor der {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity} hatten ihre Seher Visionen von der kommenden Zerst√∂rung und suchten verzweifelt nach einem Weg, diese zu √ºberleben. Die Schlangen errichteten ein magisches Stasisfeld unter ihrer Stadt und w√§hlten ihre St√§rksten und M√§chtigsten aus, um zu schlummern und das Reich wieder aufzubauen, wenn die Gefahr vor√ºber war.

Sie sind nun erwacht. Die {@creature Vos'sykriss serpentfolk|TDCSR} {@homebrew |(see page 257)} streifen nun √ºber die Insel und werden von den verweilenden {@creature Vos'skyriss serpentfolk ghost|TDCSR|Vos'skyriss serpentfolk ghosts} {@homebrew |(see page 258)} darauf vorbereitet, die Welt f√ºr sich zu beanspruchen. Als Jorlund Vohrs Expedition in das tiefste Heiligtum von Vos'sykriss vordrang, beendete sie unwissentlich den uralten Bann der Schlangen und erweckte die Schl√§fer. Schon bald wird ein l√§ngst ausgestorben geglaubtes Volk zur√ºckkehren und die Welt f√ºr sich beanspruchen.

entries.name: Other Lands of Exandria
entries: Das Land {@book Gwessar|TDCSR|2|Gwessar}, das heute weit und breit als die junge Nation Tal'Dorei bekannt ist, ist ein weitl√§ufiges, neugieriges Land voller Abenteuer, Gefahren und Ruhm. Obwohl Tal'Dorei ein Land voller gro√üer Geschichten ist, ist die Welt von Exandria weitaus gr√∂√üer und altert√ºmlicher als nur die L√§nder zwischen dem {@book Lucidian Coast|TDCSR|4|Lucidian Coast} und dem {@book Bladeshimmer Shoreline|TDCSR|4|Bladeshimmer Shoreline}. Einige dieser anderen L√§nder wurden bereits von Vox Machina und dem M√§chtigen Nein in {@i Critical Role} erforscht, liegen aber au√üerhalb des Rahmens dieses Buches. Du kannst diese L√§nder mit Dungeons, St√§dten, Charakteren und Geschichten deiner eigenen Kreation bev√∂lkern - oder dich von der Geschichte Exandrias in {@book chapter 1|TDCSR|2} dieses Buches und den Geschichten in den Kampagnen von {@i Critical Role} inspirieren lassen, um eine ganz eigene Version Exandrias zu erschaffen.

entries.name: Issylra
entries: Nordwestlich von Tal'Dorei, jenseits der eisigen Gew√§sser des Ozmit-Meeres, liegt Issylra, die Heimat von Vasselheim, das gemeinhin als die √§lteste erhaltene Stadt Exandrias bezeichnet wird. Issylra wird von den meisten als das Land angesehen, in dem die gesamte Zivilisation entstand und sich in der Zeit der {@book Founding|TDCSR|2|The Founding} ausbreitete, was es f√ºr viele zum religi√∂sen Zentrum und f√ºr andere zum Brennpunkt historischer Studien macht. Es war auch der Ort, an dem die meisten der fliegenden St√§dte der {@book Age of Arcanum|TDCSR|2|Age of Arcanum} zum ersten Mal aus dem Boden schossen. Seine Bewohner stiegen hoch auf - und fielen schwer von diesen schwindelerregenden H√∂hen, und bis heute hassen und f√ºrchten viele dort die Macht der arkanen Magie.

Das als {@book Othanzia|TDCSR|4|Issylra} bekannte Gebiet umfasst einen Gro√üteil der entwickelten Regionen des Kontinents, wobei die meisten Dom√§nen durch die Macht der Theokratie von Vasselheim gesch√ºtzt und regiert werden. Eingebettet in die √∂stlichen Taigaw√§lder des Vesperholzlandes ist die Stadt Vasselheim die √§lteste bekannte Keimzelle von Zivilisation und Religion und die einzige Stadt, die jeder Katastrophe standgehalten hat, die Exandria ersch√ºttert hat, seit die G√∂tter es zum Leben erweckten. Als spirituelles Zentrum des gr√∂√üten Teils der Welt wird Vasselheim von einer Koalition von Hohepriestern der Vielen {@book Prime Deities|TDCSR|3|Prime Deities} regiert. Diese Hierophanten werden von ihrem Volk als die Besch√ºtzer ihrer tugendhaften Gesellschaft und der gesamten {@book Othanzian|TDCSR|4|Issylra} Kultur angesehen.

Jenseits der uralten Mauern Vasselheims liegen eisige, ungez√§hmte Wildnisse, von denen einige seit der {@book Founding|TDCSR|2|The Founding} selbst unber√ºhrt sind. Diese L√§nder sind von uralten Monstern und schrecklichen Bestien bev√∂lkert. Anderswo in {@book Othanzia|TDCSR|4|Issylra} sind die L√§nder von Issylra nur sp√§rlich von verstreuten Republiken unterschiedlicher Moral bev√∂lkert. Das Reisen zwischen diesen Stadtstaaten ist schwierig, da die Bestien der {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}, die die L√§nder jenseits von Vasselheim heimgesucht haben, noch nicht verschwunden sind.

entries.name: Marquet
entries: Folgt man den Winden und Wellen s√ºdwestlich von Tal'Dorei √ºber das Ozmit-Meer, gelangt man schlie√ülich zur Inselkette des Hespet-Archipels und an die K√ºste des Kontinents {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet}. Die Kieselstr√§nde der Bucht der Geschenke begr√º√üen den Reisenden mit dem bezaubernden Anblick unber√ºhrter Natur, und die Hafenstadt Shamal l√§dt mit ihren sch√∂nen Balls√§len und vergoldeten Spielhallen zu den Freuden der Zivilisation ein.

Jenseits des Hafens von Shamal liegt der felsige Rand des Aggrad-Gebirges, dessen Schluchten und H√∂hlen unz√§hlige r√§uberische Kreaturen beherbergen, bevor sie in die riesige marquesianische W√ºste √ºbergehen. Es wird gemunkelt, dass dieses sandige √ñdland einst ein gr√ºner Dschungel war, der durch den Speer des {@deity The Ruiner|Exandria|TDCSR|Ruiner} im {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity} in den Ruin getrieben wurde. Einige Geschichten erz√§hlen von einem gro√üen Helden, der sich opferte, um {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet} vor der v√∂lligen Vernichtung zu bewahren, aber nur verstreute Fragmente dieser Geschichte sind √ºberliefert.

In der N√§he des Zentrums dieser intensiven W√ºste, umgeben von einem sich ausbreitenden Netzwerk kleiner D√∂rfer, liegt die gro√üe Stadt {@book Ank'Harel|TDCSR|4|Marquet}, bekannt als das Juwel der Hoffnung. Diese Stadt, die auf der Ertrunkenen Stadt von Cael Morrow erbaut wurde, ist das Zentrum der Kultur, Geschichte und Macht f√ºr ganz {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet}. Angef√ºhrt von dem mysteri√∂sen, unsterblichen J'mon Sa Ord ist {@book Ank'Harel|TDCSR|4|Marquet} ein gro√üartiger Ort der Musik und Kultur. Es ist nicht ohne Gefahren, aber im Vergleich zu den monsterverseuchten Sanden, die es umgeben, ist es ein Paradies.

Die H√§nde von Ord, die W√§chter der Stadt, sch√ºtzen auch die nahegelegenen D√∂rfer und Gemeinden in der W√ºste, aber sie k√∂nnen nur bis zu einer bestimmten Grenze reichen. Weiter s√ºdlich, jenseits der Reichweite von {@book Ank'Harel|TDCSR|4|Marquet} und den H√§nden von Ord, weicht der Sand dem Buschland und den S√ºmpfen, die von den unbest√§ndigen Bergen um den rauchenden Vulkan Suuthan und den gef√§hrlichen Clans, die ihn anbeten, umgeben sind. Im Westen, jenseits der trockenen W√ºste, liegt eine lebendige Landschaft mit gr√ºnen Dschungeln, zerkl√ºfteten Bergen und magischen Geheimnissen, die das Volk von {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet} seit √Ñonen entr√§tselt hat. In den Dschungeln von {@book Marquet|TDCSR|4|Marquet} gibt es Dutzende von Kulturen, einige nomadisch, einige seefahrend und einige mit eigenen gro√üen St√§dten. Eine dieser St√§dte, die von orkischen √úberlebenden des {@deity The Ruiner|Exandria|TDCSR|Ruiner's} Zorns w√§hrend des {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity} gegr√ºndet wurde, ist in ganz Exandria f√ºr ihre mathematisch makellose Architektur bekannt. Dieses Reich hei√üt Gelehrte und Reisende aus ganz Exandria willkommen, die gerne von den K√∂pfen einiger der gr√∂√üten Architekten, die die Welt je gesehen hat, lernen m√∂chten.

entries.name: The Shattered Teeth
entries: Nur wenige segeln in die gef√§hrlichen Gew√§sser s√ºd√∂stlich von Tal'Dorei, vorbei an der allgegenw√§rtigen Nebelbank, die man den Narrenvorhang nennt, und in die Zerbrochenen Z√§hne. Diese Ansammlung zerbrochener L√§ndereien besteht aus dreiundvierzig Inseln, deren Gr√∂√üe von kleinen, meilenbreiten Riffspitzen bis hin zu gro√üen, stadt√§hnlichen Inseln wie Ruukva reicht. Zwei Gesellschaften leben in den Zerbrochenen Z√§hnen. Die erste ist die Ossended Host, eine riesige Fischerkultur, die ihre Unabh√§ngigkeit - bis hin zum Isolationismus - und ihre Selbsterm√§chtigung durch die Anbetung der Macht der Tr√§ume und Alptr√§ume sch√§tzt. Die zweite ist die Wanderman-Versammlung, eine jahrhundertealte Handelsgesellschaft, die, nachdem sie in einem Taifun auf der anderen Seite der Shattered Teeth gestrandet war, zu einer brutalen, r√ºcksichtslosen Gesellschaft heranwuchs, die sich der Gewinnmaximierung um jeden Preis verschrieben hat. Sie tarnt sich schlecht unter dem Banner der Ehre und Br√ºderlichkeit.

Diese Spannungen haben in den letzten Jahren zu Blutvergie√üen gef√ºhrt, und jede Gruppe ist paranoid, dass die andere darauf aus ist, ihre Lebensweise zu zerst√∂ren. Was unter der Oberfl√§che dieses Konflikts brodelt, ist die Natur und die Quelle der Tr√§ume, die sich die Ossended Hosts seit Generationen zunutze machen, und was diese Antwort f√ºr die K√§mpfe der Menschen in den Shattered Teeths bedeuten k√∂nnte.

entries.name: Wildemount
entries: √ñstlich von Tal'Dorei gelegen, sind die L√§ndereien von Wildemount geologisch sehr vielf√§ltig, von der tropischen Menageriek√ºste √ºber die d√ºsteren und regnerischen T√§ler von West-Wynandir bis hin zu den gesprengten W√ºsten von Ost-Wynandir - besser bekannt als Xhorhas. Das Volk der Tal'Dorei treibt regen Handel mit Wildemount, obwohl die Gew√§sser der {@book Lucidian Ocean|TDCSR|4|Lucidian Coast} von Piraten, Seeungeheuern und vergessenen aquatischen Halbg√∂ttern heimgesucht werden. Eine solche Reise f√ºhrt zum Chlodwig-Konkord, einer F√∂deration von Stadtstaaten, die die Menageriek√ºste regieren, wo eine lebendige Kultur des Handels, der Unterhaltung und der K√ºnste inmitten der illegalen Aktivit√§ten lokaler Schmuggler und des allgegenw√§rtigen {@book Myriad|TDCSR|3|The Myriad} Syndikats floriert.

Im Zentrum des Kontinents herrscht das Dwendalische Reich, eine autorit√§re Macht, die ihren Einfluss auf ganz Wildemount ausdehnen will. Das Reich wird von K√∂nig Bertrand Dwendal regiert, aber die Spannungen zwischen der Krone und der Cerberus-Versammlung, der Liga der Arkanisten und Geheimagenten des Reiches, kochen hoch. Obwohl die Macht der Versammlung zu- und abnimmt, versuchen sie st√§ndig, die wahre, schattenhafte Macht hinter der dwendalischen Krone zu werden.

Die Kontrolle des Reiches √ºber die ressourcenreichen T√§ler im Zentrum von Wildemount hat es zu einer milit√§rischen Supermacht gemacht. Ebenso machen die nat√ºrlichen Verteidigungsanlagen der umliegenden Berge die L√§ndereien leicht zu verteidigen. Die Vorstellung, dass das Reich unbesiegbar ist, hat jahrhundertelang die Rekrutierungspropaganda f√ºr das Milit√§r, die scheinheilig "Gerechte Marke" genannte Armee, angeheizt. Die Erlasse von K√∂nig Dwendal haben eine √§u√üerst nationalistische Gesellschaft geschaffen, die nur die Anbetung von durch die Krone anerkannten Gottheiten zul√§sst, sich der Wehrpflicht unterwirft und in chauvinistischer Weise immense Steuern zur Unterst√ºtzung der Kriege der Krone erhebt.

Jenseits der Berge √∂stlich des Dwendalischen Reiches liegen die Ein√∂den von Xhorhas, die von der Kryn-Dynastie regiert werden. Diese Gesellschaft wurde von dunklen {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} gegr√ºndet, die dem Zugriff der {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen} durch die Gnade eines √ºbernat√ºrlichen Lichtwesens namens {@deity The Lost Beacon of Unknown Light|Exandria|TDCSR|Luxon} entkamen, das ihnen die F√§higkeit verlieh, sich in neue K√∂rper zu reinkarnieren, Leben f√ºr Leben. Diejenigen, die reinkarniert sind, versuchen, das Wissen der {@deity The Lost Beacon of Unknown Light|Exandria|TDCSR|Luxon} zu erweitern, indem sie k√ºhne Leben f√ºhren und neue Erfahrungen sammeln. Heute leben in der Kryn-Dynastie nicht nur dunkle {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, sondern auch Goblinkin, {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs}, Oger, Kobolde und alle m√∂glichen anderen V√∂lker, die vom Dwendalischen Reich als "Monster" betrachtet werden.

Jenseits der Kryn-Dynastie und des Dwendalischen Reiches und der Spannungen, die zwischen ihnen herrschen, liegen die L√§nder des Miskath-Strandes und die Inseln von Eiselcross. Beides sind Reiche, die von verbotener Magie verwirrt sind, und die von unheimlichen Abscheulichkeiten und anderen Kreaturen bewohnt werden, die ein Anthema f√ºr das sterbliche Leben darstellen. Doch trotz der Gefahren betrachten die mutigsten Abenteurer von Wildemount - und in der Tat von ganz Exandria - die Erforschung als den Gipfel des Heldentums. An den R√§ndern der bekannten Welt, wo Monster vom Rande der Realit√§t lauern... hier beginnt das wahre Abenteuer.

entries.name: Session Zero
entries: Die Spieler von {@i Critical Role} schaffen gro√üartige Geschichten, indem sie vor Beginn der Kampagne offen mit ihrem Spielleiter kommunizieren und diese Kommunikation auch zwischen den Spielsitzungen aufrechterhalten. Auf diese Weise wird sichergestellt, dass die Geschichten aller Beteiligten auf unterhaltsame Weise erz√§hlt werden und dass alle am Tisch Spa√ü haben. Um die gleiche Erfahrung zu machen, solltet ihr mit eurem Spielleiter dar√ºber sprechen, was euch wichtig ist, w√§hrend ihr euren Charakter erstellt und seine Hintergrundgeschichte ausarbeitet. Auf diese Weise kann euer Spielleiter eine Geschichte aufbauen, in der ihr und eure Verb√ºndeten die Hauptpersonen seid und nicht nur Zuschauer.

Sitzung Null ist ein Sammelbegriff f√ºr ein Treffen zwischen den Spielern (einschlie√ülich des Spielleiters) vor dem Spiel, bei dem jeder die Erwartungen und Grenzen f√ºr die Kampagne festlegen kann. Auf der {@link internet|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CqGzwhnRAk0} und in anderen B√ºchern der f√ºnften Edition finden sich viele Anleitungen, die darauf abzielen, Ihrer Kampagne einen guten Start mit Sitzung Null zu geben. In der ersten Sitzung werden oft die folgenden Punkte besprochen:

items: Was jeder Spieler und der Spielleiter an Kampagnen der f√ºnften Edition mag und was sie sich von dieser Kampagne erhoffen.
Gleiches gilt f√ºr die Aspekte des Spiels, die den Spielern nicht gefallen, mit denen sie sich unwohl f√ºhlen oder die sie aus irgendeinem Grund in dieser Kampagne einfach vermeiden wollen.
Wenn diese Kampagne ein Film w√§re, welches Rating h√§tte er? PG? PG-13? R?

Welche Themen machen im Spiel Spa√ü, welche sind aufgrund von pers√∂nlichem Unbehagen absolut tabu, und welche sind in Ma√üen in Ordnung? Jeder sollte eindeutig damit einverstanden sein, ein Spiel zu spielen, das Themen wie extreme Gewalt, romantische oder sexuelle Situationen, geschlechts-, rassen-, behinderten- oder altersbedingte Diskriminierung oder Gewalt oder Themen, die Politik oder Religion aus dem wirklichen Leben betreffen, enth√§lt.
Welchen Anteil an K√§mpfen, Erkundungen und sozialen Begegnungen die Spieler erleben wollen.
Welche Art von Charakter jeder Spieler erstellen m√∂chte und wie die Charaktere zu einer zusammenh√§ngenden Gruppe zusammenpassen k√∂nnten.

Welche Art von Geschichte wollen alle gemeinsam erleben, ob es sich um eine m√§andernde Episodengeschichte oder ein langes Epos handelt, und ob die Geschichte von den Handlungen der Spieler und ihren Konsequenzen oder von den durch den Spielleiter gesteuerten Ereignissen bestimmt werden soll.

entries: Au√üerdem finden es viele Leute hilfreich, sich nach jedem Spiel gegenseitig zu informieren und zu besprechen, was allen gefallen hat, was sie weniger oder mehr wollen, so dass der Spielleiter und die Spieler sich darauf vorbereiten k√∂nnen, mehr von dem, was funktioniert hat, in die n√§chste Sitzung mitzunehmen, und weniger von dem, was nicht funktioniert hat.

entries.name: Flavorful Details
entries: Zus√§tzlich zur Besprechung der Hintergrundgeschichte eures Charakters mit eurem Spielleiter und den anderen Spielern in eurer Gruppe k√∂nnt ihr euch weitere geschmackvolle Details √ºberlegen, die euren Charakter in der Welt von Exandria verankern.

entries.name: Gods
entries: Ein riesiges Pantheon von Gottheiten erschuf Exandria in der Urzeit. Welche dieser Gottheiten betet dein Charakter an, wenn √ºberhaupt? Betet er einen obskuren Gott an oder einen, der in den Tal'Dorei allgemein verehrt wird? Wie stark sind sie in ihrem Glauben?
Die G√∂tter Exandrias werden in {@book chapter 2|TDCSR|3} ausf√ºhrlicher beschrieben, auch wenn dein Spielleiter vielleicht einige Details dieser G√∂tter geheim halten m√∂chte.

entries.name: Factions
entries: Die Politik der Tal'Dorei wird von einer Reihe von Fraktionen beeinflusst. Nicht alle stehen sich aktiv feindlich gegen√ºber, und viele sind sogar Verb√ºndete.

Aber alle ringen st√§ndig um die Macht - und geraten dabei h√§ufig in Konflikt. Geh√∂ren Sie zu einer dieser Fraktionen? Sind Sie ein √ºberzeugtes Mitglied? Sympathisieren Sie einfach mit ihrer Sache oder haben Sie vielleicht Freunde oder Familienangeh√∂rige, die Teil der Fraktion sind? Gibt es Fraktionen, die Sie aktiv verachten, vielleicht wegen einer Kr√§nkung, die sie in der Vergangenheit gegen Sie oder Ihnen nahestehende Personen begangen haben?
Die Fraktionen der Tal'Dorei werden in {@book chapter 2|TDCSR|3} ausf√ºhrlicher beschrieben, obwohl euer Spielleiter einige Details dieser Fraktionen vielleicht geheim halten m√∂chte.

entries.name: Races and Cultures
entries: Tal'Dorei is home to manifold humanoid peoples, from the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} who emerged from the Fey Realm into the untouched lands of {@book Gwessar|TDCSR|2|Gwessar} in the wake of the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}, to the {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans} who first came to Tal'Dorei on stout ships from the distant shores of {@book Issylra|TDCSR|4|Issylra}. The familiar fantasy races of {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, and {@book halflings|TDCSR|5|halflings} are the most populous beings on Tal'Dorei, but they are far from the only peoples to make their mark in city and wilderness alike.

Over the past thousand years of history, the peoples described in this chapter have left an indelible mark on the world. And though many of these races appear monolithic at first glance, all are incredibly varied. A first-time visitor to Tal'Dorei might initially perceive all {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} as haughty and fascinated with heritage, because that's the dominant culture in {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, the largest elf-majority city on the continent. However, the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} living in villages and cities across the land are often exceptions to that apparent rule, and it's dangerous—not to mention rude—for travelers to assume that any of Tal'Dorei's varied peoples fit into simple boxes.

This section is a resource for you to use to inspire your character's backstory—or to inspire your NPCs if you're a Game Master. Whether you enjoy leaning into fantasy archetypes, intentionally breaking them, or ignoring them entirely, this section has something for you. The game statistics of each of the races of Tal'Dorei are identical to those in the fifth edition rules.

entries.name: People and Monsters
entries: For generations of roleplaying gamers in many different RPG campaign settings, certain of the fantasy peoples in the world of Exandria have long been considered "monsters" or "evil races." {@book Goblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin}, {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs}, and {@book bugbears|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} are examples of peoples whose very nature was supposedly tainted by inherent evil, and were thus morally unambiguous targets for adventurers to kill and loot. This mindset treats these people as no different from monsters like {@creature basilisk|MM|basilisks} or {@creature giant spider|MM|giant spiders}.

The humanoid people of Tal'Dorei aren't set up that way. Any creature with the humanoid type is a thinking, feeling person. Creatures with the dragon, giant, or fey type are also unambiguously sapient, and thus can have any alignment. It's just as likely for a human to be a neutral evil {@creature bandit} as it is for an orc to be a chaotic good {@creature swashbuckler|VGM}, or for a {@creature hobgoblin} to be a lawful good {@creature knight}. And if you like, you can take this even further in your games and say that any fantasy creature with an Intelligence score of 6 or higher is capable of free thought, and should have just as wide a range of alignments as other sapient beings.

The stories in {@i Critical Role} are filled with shades of moral gray, but Tal'Dorei still has plenty of unambiguously evil creatures. Most demons, devils, and undead are suffused with cosmic evil, and always try to subvert righteousness. Likewise, unthinking creatures such as oozes and constructs, and creatures of instinctual intelligence such as beasts, many monstrosities, and plant creatures, all make morally unambiguous foes.

Likewise, there are plenty of evil humanoids in the world. Cultists of evil gods, including the {@book Remnants|TDCSR|3|The Remnants} who worship {@deity The Whispered One|Exandria|TDCSR}, and merciless, blood-soaked bandits such as the {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} are clear and immediate threats to both the safety of the player characters and all free peoples of Tal'Dorei. Depending on the tone of your story, the characters might cut such foes down without mercy—or they might try to rehabilitate them. The difference is that these villains' choices, not their ancestries, determine whether or not they are evil.

entries.name: Cultures across Tal'Dorei
entries: The various peoples of Tal'Dorei don't have racial cultures. Rather, someone's culture is based on the cities and regions in which they spend their formative years. For most of Tal'Dorei's history, members of the different fantasy races lived in largely monolithic enclaves. However, the more recent past has instilled in people the need to break down old barriers, work together, and live together.

All cities and large towns have a majority population of certain races, typically based on the peoples who founded those settlements. This includes such notable sites as the elf-majority city-state of {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} and the dwarf-majority city-state of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}. Some people in Tal'Dorei might assume that certain races have common cultural traits that unite them, but many others know that this isn't the whole truth. A dwarf raised in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} and a dwarf raised in {@book Stilben|TDCSR|4|Stilben} are likely to have very different attitudes about family, food, faith, and all the other factors that make up a culture.

Even when people of the same race gather in neighborhoods within a city, those people don't necessarily share the common culture of their best-known homelands. In many neighborhoods in the great city of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, for example, {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} and half-elves are a majority. But since not all those elf-kin come from {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, they don't all share a monolithic {@book Syngornian|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} "elf culture."

That said, beings with distinctly magical traits often form cultures that include their unique abilities. This includes folk such as {@book dragonblood|TDCSR|5|dragonblood}, with their ability to channel elemental power. And because {@book goliaths|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants} are known for their powerful, muscular bodies, goliath-majority societies often worship the {@deity The Stormlord|Exandria|TDCSR|Stormlord}, god of strength, and engage in festivals that center around feats of athleticism.

entries.name: Dragonblood
entries: The dragonblood of Exandria are a people of unknown origin, and countless myths surround their ancestral creation. One particularly pervasive tale states that dragonblood were created by the {@deity The Scaled Tyrant|Exandria|TDCSR|Scaled Tyrant} and the {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon} during the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}, serving as loyal soldiers who eventually earned their freedom. Regardless of how they came into being, though, the dragonblood lived for many centuries in relative isolation in the southern wastes of Xhorhas, on the continent of {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount}.

Today, dragonblood live all over Exandria, though they remain a scarcer sight in Tal'Dorei than in {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount}. Their spread across the world was hastened by the assault against the free peoples of Exandria by the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}. During that conflict, the ancient white dragon known as Vorugal the Frigid Doom destroyed the magical city-state of Draconia, the ancestral homeland of most dragonblood.

The destruction of Draconia and the loss of many of its people was a tragedy. But to roughly half the dragonblood of Exandria, it also marked the end of an oppressive regime. Dragonblood of Exandria can either be born with a tail or without. In Draconia, those with tails were called draconians or draconbloods, for they were seen as closer in form and power to true dragons. Those without tails were given the name of ravenites and enslaved. Their blood and toil built the mighty towers of Draconia, yet the ravenites enjoyed none of their city's splendor.

The ruin of Draconia thus marked the start of an era of freedom and self-determination for the ravenites. In Tal'Dorei, it's apparent that any differences between the ravenites and the draconians have nothing to do with bloodline or draconic power. Those differences are cultural, and rooted in a past whose conflicts still haven't been resolved. The oppression that existed in Draconia remains largely unknown within Tal'Dorei to this day, and outside of major cities such as {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, dragonblood can go for months, even years, without seeing another of their kind.

entries.title:
Dragonblood
Art Credit: {@link Svetoslav Petrov|http://artstation.com/svetoslavpetrov}
entries.altText: A bronze dragonblood holding a spear and a glaive, a taller, silver dragonblood stands behind them casting a magical light spell between their hands.

entries.name: Draconians
entries: The tail-bearing draconians who survived the destruction of Draconia have been scattered across the world. In the time that's passed since the fall of the {@book dragonblood|TDCSR|5|dragonblood} city-state, a generation of draconbloods have grown up in Tal'Dorei's towns and cities, disconnected from their parents' privileged upbringing. Only a scant few draconians—typically ones able to teleport away from Vorugal's attack—escaped with any sort of wealth. Most other refugees were lucky simply to escape with their lives.

entries.name: Clinging to the Past
entries: A social divide continues to grow between draconians who have wealth and those who don't. Many of those with wealth greedily cling to the shadows of their former tyrannical glory, but other draconians seek instead to bury the past and create their own destiny, on their own merits.

entries.name: Ravenites
entries: Following the end of the Draconian order, the ravenites ventured into the world eager to make the most of their newfound freedom. In the generation since, many have formed a new homeland in Xhorhas known as Xarzith Kitril, content to reclaim the lands of their birth. Those ravenites who departed {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount} have found a new home in the cities and the icy north of Tal'Dorei, where they enjoy the freedom and privileges of equality that this land provides.

entries.name: Rebuilding from Scratch
entries: Most ravenite children grew up poor, either in slum towns at the edges of cities like {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} and {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}, or helping their parents laboriously carve out rural lives in the {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains} or {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}.

entries.name: Dwarves
entries: When the world was nearly rent asunder by the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}, the {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} of Tal'Dorei disappeared underground to wait out the worst of the conflict. Many dwarven citadels once dotted the subterranean world, but over the centuries, they dwindled, either merging together or falling into decadence and ruin. In the centuries following the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}, these dwarf clans, isolated beneath the surface of Exandria, gathered into a single, steadfast redoubt: {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}. In one way or another, just about every dwarf in Tal'Dorei can trace their family back to that great city-state.

The mountainous stronghold still stands as the heart of settlement in the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}, and many {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} consider it a place all their folk should visit at least once a decade. {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} legendary status gives it a highly conservative, unchanging culture, but even so, the dwarf people are far from monolithic.

Some {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} like to distinguish themselves as hill or mountain {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, based on whether or not they grew up outside or inside of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}. Gurdhe, a Dwarvish word translated into Common as "hill," colloquially means "beyond the mountains" in most Dwarvish dialects. And many {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, even the so-called mountain-dwellers renowned for living their entire lives underground, make journeys out into the "hills" of Tal'Dorei to trade, gain artistic inspiration, or visit the children of long-dead friends they bonded with decades or centuries prior.

entries.title:
Left: Kraghammer Dwarf, Middle: Duergar of Emberhold, Right: Hill Traveler
Art Credit: {@link Ariana Orner|http://ornerine.tumblr.com/}
entries.altText: Three dwarves stand together. On the left is a Kraghammer dwarf clad in heavy, bronze armor,  bearing a polearm. On the right is a Hill Traveler with red braids in her hair, leaning on a warhammer. Between them is a Duergar with spiked white hair and bearing a battleaxe.

entries.name: Kraghammer Dwarves
entries: The culture of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} is one of isolationism and tradition—even to the point of xenophobia. As a common saying goes: "Those who live beneath the mountain are as unmoving as the mountain itself." Whether they're {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes}, or folk of other ancestries, the people who dwell in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} typically embody this stubborn, dogmatic stoicism.

entries.name: Tradition
entries: {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} society is steeped in a culture of {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} protecting their own, and those {@book dwarves'|TDCSR|5|dwarves} traditions of meticulous chronicling, geometrically precise artistry, dynastic great houses, and resilience against even the greatest of threats has proved itself a central pillar of their society. For long centuries, new peoples and new ideas in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} meant potential danger, threatening the death of monarchs and incursion by nefarious subterranean infiltrators. The first time that {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} proudly opened its gates to a new people, the oligarch Warren {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} led all of Tal'Dorei into the greatest war since the {@book Age of Arcanum|TDCSR|2|Age of Arcanum}. The city's relative safety during the assault of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} only cemented its people's belief that isolation is strength.

entries.name: Change
entries: In the present day, many of {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} residents feel stifled by its dominant culture, which continues to be insular and suspicious of outsiders and new ideas. In the past few decades, a tide of refugees fleeing crises such as the {@book Wittebak disaster|TDCSR|4|Pools of Wittebak} and the {@book Cinder King's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} attack on {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} have brought new voices and perspectives to the formerly unyielding halls of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}. These people now call the {@book dwarves'|TDCSR|5|dwarves} ancestral realm their home, and many of {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} have seen the innovation and transformation that new residents can bring. Change comes slowly in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, but it does come in time.

entries.name: Hill Travelers
entries: {@book Dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} might leave their underground realm for myriad reasons, with many making homesteads in the foothills of the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} or venturing even farther afield. Hill {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} who left the mountain themselves, or who had parents or more distant ancestors who did so, have a certain shared camaraderie in their connection to the open sky above, the sun and wind around them, and the soft loam beneath their feet.

entries.name: Exploration
entries: It's common for {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} who live upon the hills and fields of Tal'Dorei to wander throughout their lives, never putting down roots for more than a decade or two at a time out of their centuries-long lives. {@book Dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} with tanned skin and sun-bleached hair are so common a sight in taverns across the {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains} that the Dwarvish word gurdheledr, translated as "hill travelers," has come to mean "mercenary" or "bounty hunter" as commonly as it refers to simple wanderers.

entries.name: Community
entries: {@book Dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} are a common sight in cities such as {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} and {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}, and even in smaller towns across central Tal'Dorei. Not unlike mountain-dwelling {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, these city dwellers are often as unmoving as a granite boulder on a rock shelf—unable to be budged unless given a tremendous push. {@book Dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} typically adopt the culture of wherever they live, though their long lives sometimes make them more resistant to social change than shorter-lived peoples.

entries.name: Duergar of Emberhold
entries: Deep beneath Tal'Dorei is an underground realm lit only by magelight, magma flows, luminescent creatures and fungi, and the roaring fires of duergar forges. It is thought that a group of {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} delved far into the depths of Exandria countless centuries ago, predating even the chronicles of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}. Whether by choice or by necessity, they made a home in the caverns they explored there. Something about the magic that suffuses their eerie realm changed the deep {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}—who are called the duergar now. That name was originally an epithet, bestowed by the mountain {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} who rediscovered and battled those deep {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, but the duergar now wear it with pride.

entries.name: Survival
entries: The deep caverns of Tal'Dorei are an inhospitable place, filled with creatures whose aberrant forms defy imagination and whose alien minds reject mortal morality. The duergar became hardened by their struggle for survival, and their rejection at the hands of the {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} hardened their hearts forever. The smiths of the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} do not forge art or works of beauty—only weapons and armor to turn back the onslaught of those who wish to see them dead.

entries.name: Alliance
entries: The duergar have suffered alone for so long, hating all and hated by all. Nevertheless, in the undercurrents of the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold}, the idea spreads that there must be more to life than fire and death. Many duergar nurture a secret hope of finding some way to ally with their other dwarf kin—if only someone were brave enough to reach out a hand without fear of it being cut off.

entries.name: Elemental Ancestry
entries: Exandria's lands are rife with elemental power. Primordial energy constantly flows into the world from elemental rifts, and such primal power inevitably alters its surroundings. This is also true of peoples who spend long years in proximity to such sources of power, and of those who travel the planes long enough to find the seed of elemental power take root within their blood. Such folk are the beginning of an elemental ancestry, harboring the potential to give birth to children who are suffused with latent magic.

Children of an elemental ancestry bear the features of their parents' ancestry, but have clearly become something new. Their appearance is altered by their power, granting them skin that shines like the sun on the surface of the sea, hair that crackles like flame, or eyes that glitter like gemstones. Then comes the manifestation of elemental powers, which can make a child the envy of their peers—or someone to be feared.

While people of elemental ancestry are rare in Tal'Dorei, they are most common among {@book the Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari} due to the elemental affinity of that folk. Some possessed of elemental power enjoy the attention their uniqueness garners them. But for others, even the most benign interest draws painful attention to their otherness.

entries.title:
Elemental Ancestry
Art Credit: {@link Nikki Dawes|http://nikkidawes.artstation.com/}
entries.altText: An older woman wearing a blacksmith's apron holds a sword she is crafting. She has fiery streaks in her long, white hair. The sword glows orange, heated by her elemental magic.

entries.name: Belonging
entries: People with an elemental bloodline are often raised by parents in a regular community, and so grow up with all the aspirations and prejudices inherent to their culture. For many such people, the traits that make them unique also make them a pillar of their community—for example, a baker who instinctually understands the will of her oven's fire. Within superstitious lands and cultures, however, a person's elemental powers might make them the target of scrutiny, fearmongering, or jealousy, eventually driving them to strike out into the world to seek a place where they truly belong.

entries.name: Called to the Ashari
entries: Those elemental-touched people who leave their communities often seek out {@book the Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari}, the isolated keepers of rifts to the Elemental Planes. Elementally attuned children are born with great frequency to {@book the Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari}, who understand the utmost importance of giving those children the education and training that will let them understand their gifts.

All people of {@book elemental ancestry|TDCSR|5|Elemental Ancestry} are welcome among {@book the Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari}, including the Air Ashari and Earth Ashari found in Tal'Dorei. However, even those whose {@book elemental ancestry|TDCSR|5|Elemental Ancestry} connects them to water or fire can seek out Tal'Dorei's Ashari peoples to help them on their journeys of discovery. In time, such a journey might lead them to the Fire Ashari on the continent of {@book Issylra|TDCSR|4|Issylra}, to the Water Ashari on the Islands of Anamn in the Ozmit Sea, or to Ashari who have journeyed from those lands to Tal'Dorei.

Elementally attuned folk who don't seek or can't find {@book the Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari} might instead find their way to the reclusive {@book giants of Tal'Dorei|TDCSR|7|Giantkin}. Though the giants do their best to keep their distance from the lives and problems of humanoids, they have been known to take a shine to people whose shared elemental affinities give them common ground.

entries.name: Elves
entries: When the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity} threatened to annihilate all life on Tal'Dorei, the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} of this land gathered in their last remaining city, {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, and used long-forgotten magic to transport themselves into the Fey Realm. Time runs strangely in that realm, and for an unknown stretch of history, the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} of {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} lived with their fey kindred in peace. When they eventually returned to Exandria, they found a land devoid of all but animals and the grandeur of nature. The rotten majesty of the {@book Age of Arcanum|TDCSR|2|Age of Arcanum}, burned away by the wrath of the gods, had given way to new growth.

To the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, the lands of Tal'Dorei are still called {@book Gwessar|TDCSR|2|Gwessar}, and {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} who dwell here are called the gwes'alfen—the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} of the Fields of Joy. For centuries, this folk watched with delight as other peoples populated {@book Gwessar|TDCSR|2|Gwessar}, beginning with {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, then {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans} from across the sea, and so on. Then they looked on in horror as mortal ambition was perverted into greed, and war followed in its wake.

{@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} and the {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse} that surrounds it are the ancestral homeland of Tal'Dorei's {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, many of whom never venture beyond that homeland. Young {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} are most likely to journey afield to see what else the world has to offer, and while most of them return to {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, some make new homes in the many towns and cities of Tal'Dorei—or they become hermits, their status as mystical beings with a thousand-year life span commanding an almost mythic reverence from other folk.

The {@book elves'|TDCSR|5|elves} tendency to focus on the past has given rise to many stereotypes of those folk being haughty, aloof, and unconcerned with the day-to-day joys and sorrows of the shorter-lived races. But though this is certainly true for some {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, it's hard for other folk to consider the perspective of an elf who has personally witnessed whole cultures and civilizations rise and fall. Most {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} are born with the same passion for life as any other being. But as centuries pass, life becomes a stream of historic events to be witnessed and contemplated, and not to be interfered with unless absolutely necessary.

entries.title:
Left: Lyrengorn Elf, Middle: Syngorn Elf, Right: Dark Elf.
Art Credit: {@link Claudia Ianniciello|http://artstation.com/claudiasg}
entries.altText: Three elves stand together. On left is a Lyrengorn elf woman ornately dressed in a beautiful silken ivory gown. On right is a dark elf in rich purple and black robes. She has white hair and casts a spell with a faint, green glow. Between them is a Syngorn elf archer dressed in green robes. He bears a drawn bow and arrow.

entries.name: Syngorn Elves
entries: The syn'alfen, as the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} of the {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse} call themselves, almost universally revere the ancient history of {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, and the story of how its escape to the Fey Realm saved their culture from extinction. No elf who lives in {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} can forget this past, and {@book Syngornian|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} culture can sometimes feel overbearing to those who see it only from the outside. More than a few woodland {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} also feel stifled by their homeland's unrelenting focus on history, magic, the fey, and the preservation of elvenkind. Such {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} are most likely to leave {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} and make their homes in other parts of Tal'Dorei.

entries.name: Departure
entries: Many {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} who leave {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} (or who had parents who left) still consider themselves syn'alfen, whether they live in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} or other cities, or even the ancestral homes of other folk, such as {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}. The cultural imprint of {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} is hard to escape, and most of these expatriate wood {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} hold a certain amount of love for their home even as part of a complicated relationship.

entries.name: Reunited Family
entries: South of the {@book Stormcrest Mountains|TDCSR|4|Stormcrest Mountains} lies the massive jungle of {@book Rifenmist|TDCSR|4|Rifenmist Jungle}, home to the nomadic elf {@book Orroyen tribes|TDCSR|4|Orroyen Tribes}. The {@book Orroyen|TDCSR|4|Orroyen Tribes} believe that they split off from the {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} centuries ago, with both peoples meeting each other again only within the past century. Though initially suspicious, both elf lines soon came to see one another as longlost family.

The onslaught of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} disrupted communication with the {@book Orroyen elves|TDCSR|4|Orroyen Tribes}, and news from the south has grown more dire since. {@book Orroyen|TDCSR|4|Orroyen Tribes} refugees continue to flow into {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, fleeing the tyrannical {@book Iron Authority|TDCSR|4|Tz'Arrm, Helm of the Emperor} that rules {@book Rifenmist|TDCSR|4|Rifenmist Jungle}.

entries.name: Lyrengorn Elves
entries: The lyren'alfen, known alternately as Lyrengorn {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} or high {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, are a people who broke off from {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} long ago, and who journeyed from southern Tal'Dorei to settle in the frigid {@book Neverfields|TDCSR|4|The Neverfields}, north of the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}. The city of Lyrengorn that they founded is every bit as majestic as {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} in the south, but for better or worse, Lyrengorn lacks its sister city's millennia of culture—and its cultural baggage.

entries.name: Art and Expression
entries: Lyrengorn is nestled in the spires of the {@book Elvenpeaks|TDCSR|4|Lyrengorn, the Elvenpeaks}, spreading under the mysterious northern lights known as the {@deity The Moonweaver|Exandria|TDCSR|Moonweaver's} Ribbons. The city is always aglow with magical light, and its people are taught spellcraft from a young age, for magic is the foundation upon which Lyrengorn was built. The spells of heat and comfort woven into its residents' clothing and architecture are essential to living comfortably in such relentlessly cold lands.

The {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} who make their home within the pines of the {@book Elvenpeaks|TDCSR|4|Lyrengorn, the Elvenpeaks} are best known for riding through the wintry skies on {@creature wyvern|MM|wyverns}. Every year, people from across Tal'Dorei travel to the {@book Elvenpeaks|TDCSR|4|Lyrengorn, the Elvenpeaks} to watch skyswimmers, elite {@creature wyvern|MM|wyvern} riders who shape the glow of the {@deity The Moonweaver|Exandria|TDCSR|Moonweaver's} Ribbons from the air.

entries.name: Magic and Transformation
entries: High elf culture values magical prowess above almost all else, but the high {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} lack the dogma of many of their {@book Syngornian|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} cousins. Their society encourages experimentation, both in terms of magic and self-expression. Likewise, lyren'alfen who become adventurers often do so in pursuit of inspiration or self-discovery. High elf societies are filled with elf magi who use magic to transform their bodies, exploring different gender expressions and social roles—and they encourage all who visit Lyrengorn to join them in discovering all the different facets of one's self.

Many high {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} become religious sorcerers, exploring their latent powers through their faith. Others develop their arcane skill by seeking admission to the {@book Alabaster Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum} in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, where they study the theory of magic with the best minds from across Tal'Dorei.

entries.name: Dark Elves
entries: The myrk'alfen, also known as drow or dark {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, have a complicated relationship with the other elven societies of Tal'Dorei. Though the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} are one people by heritage, the dark {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} refused to join with the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} of {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} during the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}, instead escaping into the trackless caverns that stretched beneath Tal'Dorei. There, they became the unwitting prey of the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen}, a Betrayer God of immense cruelty.

entries.name: Betrayed by the Gods
entries: In times long past, the drow were a wise, beautiful folk with long, silvery hair and radiant ashen or violet skin. But their underground enclaves grew decadent and cruel, and their leaders fell to the alluring whispers of the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen}. The myrk'alfen allied with their venomous goddess against the {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} and their {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} in the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}. When the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen} was defeated, the myrk'alfen of Tal'Dorei were exiled permanently from the surface world, confined to their imperious realm within the earth.

entries.name: Struggle to Survive
entries: More evil powers than just the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen} lurk beneath the surface of the world. With the drow in exile, the whispers of the {@deity The Crawling King|Exandria|TDCSR|Crawling King} and the {@deity The Chained Oblivion|Exandria|TDCSR|Chained Oblivion} first reached the ears of their nobility as the dark {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} struggled to stave away the aberrations that encircled their cities. Now, generations later, the dark {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} are a people seemingly on the brink of annihilation. Neighbors slaughter one another in the streets as they succumb to paranoia. For when aberrations can take or shape any form, who can be trusted? Unable to stop their citizens from rioting, the drow elite have grown ever more authoritarian, commanding their royal guards to keep order by violently suppressing their people.

Against this ongoing chaos, some dark {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} who fall deep into the abominable thrall of the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen} become truly monstrous, their skin and eyes turning deathly pale as they become little more than puppets for their tormenting goddess. Others willingly offer themselves to the aberrations to end their suffering, and are transformed into shapeshifting {@creature doppelganger|MM|doppelgangers}. And the most power-hungry drow nobles often succumb entirely to their devotion to the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen}, willingly drinking her abyssal blood to become {@creature drider|MM|driders} in her service.

entries.name: New Light for the Shadow
entries: The people of Tal'Dorei have recently received emissaries from dark {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} who live in the eastern reaches of {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount}, in a nation called the Kryn Dynasty. Their Bright Queen, Leylas Kryn, broke free of the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen's} corrupting influence and led her people to glory and self-determination in the distant lands of Xhorhas. This rebellion was inspired by the discovery of the {@deity The Lost Beacon of Unknown Light|Exandria|TDCSR|Luxon}, a mysterious being of light and rebirth that the Kryn drow worship as a god.

Though the dark {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} of the Kryn Dynasty have problems enough of their own, some of the Kryn seek the aid of {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} and Lyrengorn on expeditions into the depths beneath Tal'Dorei. Their goals are noble, but none can deny that these are missionary expeditions in search of new followers—and in search of new {@deity The Lost Beacon of Unknown Light|Exandria|TDCSR|Luxon} beacons, the scattered fragments of that new drow god.

Many adventuring drow harbor a violent hatred of aberrations, and have abandoned the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen's} faith to become paladins in service of the {@deity The Dawnfather|Exandria|TDCSR|Dawnfather} or the {@deity The Lost Beacon of Unknown Light|Exandria|TDCSR|Luxon}, setting aside their affinity for the shadow to search for hope in the light of the sun.

entries.name: Firbolgs
entries: Fur-covered folk with floppy ears, flat noses, and long faces, firbolgs are a humanoid people with a unique, somewhat bovine appearance. They aren't insular by nature, but they feel most at ease when surrounded by the natural world, leading the vast majority of firbolgs to never leave their forest homes except under circumstances beyond their control. As a result, many folk in Tal'Dorei don't even know that firbolgs exist. Those firbolgs who do live in the realm's cosmopolitan cities either grow annoyed or accepting of people constantly questioning who—or what—they are.

entries.title:
Firbolg
Art Credit: {@link Nikki Dawes|http://nikkidawes.artstation.com/}
entries.altText: A firbolg with long white hair wearing a simple tunic, a multicoloured flower crown, and holding a large bouquet of colourful flowers in their left arm. They are holding a single red rose in their right hand.

entries.name: Dwellers of Cold Forests
entries: {@book Firbolgs'|TDCSR|5|firbolgs} fuzzy bodies are acclimated to cold weather, and they often overheat in warm climes. They are most commonly seen in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, {@book Zephrah|TDCSR|4|Zephrah}, {@book Whitestone|TDCSR|4|Whitestone}, and {@book Stilben|TDCSR|4|Stilben}, both as residents and as traveling bards and merchants. But they are otherwise a rare sight south of the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}, though some {@book firbolgs|TDCSR|5|firbolgs} enjoy a comfortable life in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} after learning a few handy spells to keep cool in the summer.

The largest and densest population of {@book firbolgs|TDCSR|5|firbolgs} in Tal'Dorei is found in the eternally winter-bound forest of the {@book Frostweald|TDCSR|4|The Frostweald}. These {@book firbolgs|TDCSR|5|firbolgs} have a friendly but cautious relationship with the capricious fey who also dwell there.

entries.name: Gnomes
entries: Gnomes and gnomish culture are relatively uncommon in Tal'Dorei, for although {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans} and rock gnomes both hail from {@book Issylra|TDCSR|4|Issylra}, relatively few gnomes have the chance or the desire to leave their homeland. Moreover, their short stature has often proved a social hindrance in the lands of taller folk. But where they have settled, gnomes easily prove their mettle through deed and humor, becoming welcome members of the settlements where they choose to make their homes.

entries.title:
Left: Forest Gnome, Right: Rock Gnome
Art Credit: {@link Zuzanna Wuzyk|http://artstation.com/zuzartii}
entries.altText: Two gnomes stand together. On right is a forest gnome. He wears a green cloak over a green tunic and has a magical glow emitting from between his hands. On right is a rock gnome. She is a tinkerer dressed in leather apron, bronze pauldron and bearing some clockwork mechanism in her hands.

entries.name: Rock Gnomes
entries: The first {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} to enter Tal'Dorei migrated from {@book Issylra|TDCSR|4|Issylra} during the {@book Age of Arcanum|TDCSR|2|Age of Arcanum}, and endured the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity} within the deep caverns of the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}. These folk called themselves rock {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes}, and founded a marvelous settlement called {@book Wittebak|TDCSR|4|Pools of Wittebak}. Their society prized cleverness above all other things, eschewing the arts of magic for a focus on tinkering and an understanding of natural phenomena.

entries.name: Dizzying Heights
entries: By the end of the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}, the city of {@book Wittebak|TDCSR|4|Pools of Wittebak} was the most technologically advanced place in all of Tal'Dorei, even as the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} and {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} were emerging from their isolation. However, such greatness could not last. The rock {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} boasted of their superiority to the "ignorant" stone giants who also called the mountains home, and incurred their elemental wrath. In the earthquakes that followed, {@book Wittebak|TDCSR|4|Pools of Wittebak} and most of its people were destroyed.

entries.name: Eyes Ahead
entries: Most of those who survived the {@book Wittebak|TDCSR|4|Pools of Wittebak} disaster made their way to {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, relying upon the generosity of the {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} to survive. A few others traveled to {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} and {@book Kymal|TDCSR|4|Kymal}, and helped build those cities in their earliest days. To this day, most {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} with any connection to the heady era of {@book Wittebak|TDCSR|4|Pools of Wittebak} still call themselves rock {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} in its honor. These {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} carry a certain cultural memory of their city's fall from grace, which drives many of them to strive constantly toward greatness.

entries.name: Eyes Behind
entries: A fair few rock {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} dwelling in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}—elders in particular—take a different view of their people's fall from grace and glory. These {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} work bitterly and tirelessly, fueled by spite and pride, with the intention of either reclaiming {@book Wittebak|TDCSR|4|Pools of Wittebak} or proving that the city's lost technology is superior to any magic or other force on Exandria.

entries.name: Forest Gnomes
entries: Forest {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} are not native to Tal'Dorei, but unlike rock {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes}, they are believed to hail from the Fey Realm, much like the {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}. A half dozen small forest gnome communities can be found in the {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse}, hidden from the prying eyes of {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves} and human explorers alike. But how {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} ended up in the Fey Realm to begin with is a mystery that even they can't begin to answer.

entries.name: Magic, Not Tech
entries: The biggest difference between the {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} of the forest and their rock gnome cousins are their philosophies toward magic and technology. After spending untold centuries in the Fey Realm, forest {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} have a great respect for magic, especially capricious, unpredictable magic like that of the fey. Forest gnome culture sees technology as predictable and boring, even if its usefulness must be conceded from time to time.

Forest {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} respect the rock {@book gnomes'|TDCSR|5|gnomes} dedication to science, and are more than happy to help their kin in their search to understand how nature works and how to manipulate it. But in the end, knowledge is not as important as canniness in forest gnome enclaves.

entries.name: Worldly Explorers
entries: Not all forest {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} are as close to their fey identity as the {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} of the {@book Verdant Expanse|TDCSR|4|Verdant Expanse}, and a number of more worldly clans have spread to other forests across Tal'Dorei. Most notably, a number of families, including the Trickfoot clan, have made the {@book Bramblewood|TDCSR|4|The Bramblewood} outside of {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} their home for generations. These clans are more practical than their fey kin and less uptight than their distant rock gnome cousins, giving these {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} a curious personality perfect for the life of a traveling adventurer.

entries.name: Goblinkin
entries: {@book Goblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin}, {@book hobgoblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin}, and {@book bugbears|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} are three distinct races with a united past. They live across Tal'Dorei, most often in isolated communities, though many people in the realm have become used to the sight of goblin children playing catch in the street, hobgoblin mercenaries hanging around job boards, and bugbear apothecaries running shops in the hills.

The origin of the goblinkin is shrouded in myth and legend, but it's generally accepted that these peoples were created by the {@deity The Strife Emperor|Exandria|TDCSR|Strife Emperor} during the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity} to be his perfect soldiers. The few records of that time hint that the goblinkin were once a single folk called the dranassar, a humanoid people of golden skin and green, violet, or yellow eyes who lived in eastern {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount}. They dwelled in great numbers in the city of Ghor Dranas, which came to be the seat of the {@book Betrayer Gods'|TDCSR|3|Betrayer Gods} power in the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}.

For centuries, goblinkin were viewed as monsters by most other people of Tal'Dorei—particularly explorers and adventurers who regularly invaded and destroyed goblinkin settlements. But this ugly sentiment has undergone a radical shift in the past generation, during which countless {@book goblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin}, {@book hobgoblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin}, and {@book bugbears|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} have fought alongside the other folk of Tal'Dorei in defense of their homeland against the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} and other threats. Today, goblinkin are a welcome sight in Tal'Dorei's cities, and those folk who nurture old hostilities are invariably taken to task by the people around them.

entries.title:
Left: Hobgoblin, Middle: Bugbear, Right: Goblin
Art Credit: {@link Nguyen Hieu|http://artstation.com/wthieu153}
entries.altText: Three goblinkin. The hobgoblin on the left has black hair pulled back, red skin, and is wearing full armour, has a sword on her back, and a shield on her right forearm. The bugbear in the centre has dark fur, is wearing green cloth holding a scythe in one hand and a bundle of greenery in his other hand. On the right is a smaller goblin with green skin wearing brown and white clothes, wrapping a white bandage around her forearm.

entries.name: Goblins
entries: {@book Goblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} are a green-skinned people, short of stature and typically having thin, dexterous fingers and strong, nimble legs. They fit easily into settlements with significant gnome or halfling populations, whose residences and furniture are already appropriately sized. With long traditions of living in isolated family units in forests and mountain caves, many city-dwelling {@book goblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} dwell in large houses holding at least three generations of family and many different branches of their family tree.

entries.name: Hobgoblins
entries: Most {@book hobgoblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} are alike in stature to {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans} and have similar variations in build, ranging from thin and scrawny to broad shouldered and muscular. Their large ears, gleaming yellow eyes, and powerful incisors give them a vaguely feline appearance.

{@book Hobgoblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} are often stereotyped as having a warlike, martial nature—a sentiment that arose from rumors surrounding the {@book Iron Authority|TDCSR|4|Tz'Arrm, Helm of the Emperor} in the {@book Rifenmist Jungle|TDCSR|4|Rifenmist Jungle}. That empire is majority {@creature hobgoblin}, and its cruel leaders have press-ganged the land's entire population into compulsory military service. In ages past, most {@book hobgoblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} that became known to the other peoples of Tal'Dorei were scouts or captured legionnaires of the {@book Iron Authority|TDCSR|4|Tz'Arrm, Helm of the Emperor}. Today, though, many escapees from the authority's influence live in cities such as {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, {@book Kymal|TDCSR|4|Kymal}, or {@book Byroden|TDCSR|4|Byroden}. Most of these free {@book hobgoblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} know only their parents' stories of that distant empire, and are able to live happily free of its influence.

entries.name: Bugbears
entries: {@book Bugbears|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} are tall humanoids covered with brown, black, or blue-gray fur, which combines with large ears and yellow eyes to give them an even more feline appearance than their {@creature hobgoblin} cousins. Though {@book bugbears|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} are tall, their posture is generally stooped, so that their heads are still roughly at human height.

Many {@book bugbears|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} are solitary folk, living in forests and mountains where their thick fur protects them against the cold. They typically gather in large groups one to three times a year to socialize and play games with friends, reunite with family, and find love—a tradition that has been reworked by those who live in permanent communities. Such {@book bugbears|TDCSR|5|goblinkin} often live with a number of romantic partners under the same roof, or "adopt" {@creature goblin} families and dwell in their loving, chaotic, multigenerational households.

entries.name: Half-Giants
entries: Four peoples were known to exist on Tal'Dorei when the world was reborn out of the ashes of the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}. The {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, who emerged from the Fey Realm. The {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, who emerged from the earth. The {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs}, who endured the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity} through strength and determination. And the half-giants, who safely rode out that war in mountaintop retreats before eventually descending to the windswept plains below.

Averaging seven feet tall, with hairless, craggy bodies and skin tough as stone, half-giants are often colloquially known as stoneborn or {@book goliaths|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants}. Descended from {@creature stone giant|MM|stone giants}, these folk have long been viewed as exemplars of rugged endurance and individualism. They are found in settlements across Tal'Dorei, where they are known for their innate strength and their commonly held belief—passed down from the giants of old—that all must take fate into their own hands.

In ancient times, {@book goliaths|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants} and {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs} lived off the same land, and their nomadic clans frequently warred and intermingled in equal measure. As such, it is common for {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs} and {@book goliaths|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants} of Tal'Dorei to discover common ancestors somewhere in their family trees.

entries.title:
Half-Giant
Art Credit: {@link Nikki Dawes|http://nikkidawes.artstation.com/}
entries.altText: A pale-skinned half-giant sits on a chair backwards, leaning on the chairback. She is a bit too large for the chair. She wears a yellow tunic, green pants and has black tattoos down her arms and on her head.

entries.name: Nomadic Herds
entries: Stone giants believe that physical perfection is the world's greatest virtue, and this belief has been passed down culturally to the {@book goliaths|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants} who live in the mountains and upon the {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains}. These plains-dwelling {@book half-giants|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants} call their clans "herds," and unite behind the stone giants' philosophy of "might makes right." Though at one time these herds were mostly made up of stoneborn almost exclusively, recent generations have come to include {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs}, {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, and even physically diminutive people such as {@book halflings|TDCSR|5|halflings}—as long as they agree with the philosophy of strength above all.
